column1: Enchanted creature gets +1/+2."; "• You don't choose whether the spell is going to be an Aura spell or not until the spell is already on the stack. Abilities that affect when you can cast a spell
column2: such as flash
column3: will apply to the spell after you've made this choice. For example
column4: an effect that said you can cast creature spells as though they have flash won't allow you to cast a creature card with bestow as an Aura spell anytime you could cast an instant
column5: but one that said you can cast Aura spells as though they have flash will.

column1: • On the stack
column2: a spell with bestow is either a creature spell or an Aura spell. It's never both
column3: although it's an enchantment spell in either case.

column1: • Unlike other Aura spells
column2: an Aura spell with bestow isn't countered if its target is illegal as it begins to resolve. Rather
column3: the effect making it an Aura spell ends
column4: it loses enchant creature
column5: it returns to being an enchantment creature spell
column6: and it resolves and enters the battlefield as an enchantment creature.

column1: • Unlike other Auras
column2: an Aura with bestow isn't put into its owner's graveyard if it becomes unattached. Rather
column3: the effect making it an Aura ends
column4: it loses enchant creature
column5: and it remains on the battlefield as an enchantment creature. It can attack (and its {T} abilities can be activated
column6: if it has any) on the turn it becomes unattached if it's been under your control continuously
column7: even as an Aura
column8: since your most recent turn began.

column1: • If a permanent with bestow enters the battlefield by any method other than being cast
column2: it will be an enchantment creature. You can't choose to pay the bestow cost and have it become an Aura.

column1: • Auras attached to a creature don't become tapped when the creature becomes tapped. Except in some rare cases
column2: an Aura with bestow remains untapped when it becomes unattached and becomes a creature.

column1: • An Aura that becomes a creature is no longer put into its owner's graveyard as a state-based action. Rather

Each creature you tap while casting this spell pays for {1} or one mana of that creature's color.)"; "• The rules for convoke have changed slightly since it last appeared in an expansion. Previously
column2: convoke reduced the cost to cast a spell. Under current rules
column3: you tap creatures at the same time you pay the spell's costs. Tapping a creature this way is simply another way to pay.

column1: • Convoke doesn't change a spell's mana cost or converted mana cost.
• When calculating a spell's total cost
column2: include any alternative costs
column3: additional costs
column4: or anything else that increases or reduces the cost to cast the spell. Convoke applies after the total cost is calculated.

column1: • Because convoke isn't an alternative cost
column2: it can be used in conjunction with alternative costs.

column1: • Tapping a multicolored creature using convoke will pay for {1} or one mana of your choice of any of that creature's colors.
• When using convoke to cast a spell with {X} in its mana cost
column2: first choose the value for X. That choice
column3: plus any cost increases or decreases
column4: will determine the spell's total cost. Then you can tap creatures you control to help pay that cost. For example
column5: if you cast Chord of Calling (a spell with convoke and mana cost {X}{G}{G}{G}) and choose X to be 3
column6: the total cost is {3}{G}{G}{G}. If you tap two green creatures and two red creatures
column7: you'll have to pay {1}{G}.

column1: • If a creature you control has a mana ability with {T} in the cost
column2: activating that ability while casting a spell with convoke will result in the creature being tapped when you pay the spell's costs. You won't be able to tap it again for convoke. Similarly
column3: if you sacrifice a creature to activate a mana ability while casting a spell with convoke
column4: that creature won't be on the battlefield when you pay the spell's costs
column5: so you won't be able to tap it for convoke."

Creatures you control with the chosen name have haste."; "• Conspiracies are never put into your deck. Instead
column2: you put any number of conspiracies from your card pool into the command zone as the game begins. These conspiracies are face up unless they have hidden agenda
column3: in which case they begin the game face down.

column1: • A conspiracy doesn't count as a card in your deck for purposes of meeting minimum deck size requirements. (In most drafts
column2: the minimum deck size is 40 cards.)

column1: • You don't have to play with any conspiracy you draft. However
column2: you have only one opportunity to put conspiracies into the command zone
column3: as the game begins. You can't put conspiracies into the command zone after this point.

column1: • You can look at any player's face-up conspiracies at any time. You'll also know how many face-down conspiracies a player has in the command zone
column2: although you won't know what they are.

column1: • A conspiracy's static and triggered abilities function as long as that conspiracy is face-up in the command zone.
• Conspiracies are colorless
column2: have no mana cost
column3: and can't be cast as spells.

column1: • Conspiracies aren't legal for any sanctioned Constructed format
column2: but may be included in other Limited formats
column3: such as Cube Draft.

column1: • You name the card as the game begins
column2: as you put the conspiracy into the command zone
column3: not as you turn the face-down conspiracy face up.

column1: • There are several ways to secretly name a card
column2: including writing the name on a piece of paper that's kept with the face-down conspiracy. If you have multiple face-down conspiracies
column3: you may name a different card for each one. It's important that each named card is clearly associated with only one of the conspiracies.

column1: • You must name a Magic card. Notably
column2: you can't name a token (except in the unusual case that a token's name matches the name of a card
column3: such as Illusion).

column1: • If you play multiple games after the draft
column2: you can name a different card in each new game.

column1: • As a special action
column2: you may turn a face-down conspiracy face up. You may do so any time you have priority. This action doesn't use the stack and can't be responded to. Once face up
column3: the named card is revealed and the conspiracy's abilities will affect the game.

column1: • At the end of the game
column2: you must reveal any face-down conspiracies you own in the command zone to all players.

column1: • A conspiracy with hidden agenda that has a triggered ability must be face up before that ability's trigger condition is met in order for it to trigger. Turning it face up afterward won't have any effect.
• At the end of the game
column2: you must reveal any face-down conspiracies you own in the command zone to all players. Notably
column3: you can't bluff conspiracies with hidden agenda by putting other cards into the command zone face down as the game starts."

column2: and lets you turn the face-down permanent face up any time you have priority by paying its morph cost.

column1: • The face-down spell has no mana cost and has a converted mana cost of 0. When you cast a face-down spell
column2: put it on the stack face down so no other player knows what it is
column3: and pay {3}. This is an alternative cost.

column1: • When the spell resolves
column2: it enters the battlefield as a 2/2 creature with no name
column3: mana cost
column4: creature types
column5: or abilities. It's colorless and has a converted mana cost of 0. Other effects that apply to the creature can still grant it any of these characteristics.

column1: • Any time you have priority
column2: you may turn the face-down creature face up by revealing what its morph cost is and paying that cost. This is a special action. It doesn't use the stack and can't be responded to. Only a face-down permanent can be turned face up this way; a face-down spell cannot.

column1: • Because the permanent is on the battlefield both before and after it's turned face up
column2: turning a permanent face up doesn't cause any enters-the-battlefield abilities to trigger.

column1: • A permanent that turns face up or face down changes characteristics but is otherwise the same permanent. Spells and abilities that were targeting that permanent
column2: as well as Auras and Equipment that were attached to the permanent
column3: aren't affected.

column1: • At any time
column2: you can look at a face-down spell or permanent you control. You can't look at face-down spells or permanents you don't control unless an effect instructs you to do so.

column1: • You must ensure that your face-down spells and permanents can easily be differentiated from each other. Common methods for doing this include using markers or dice
column2: or simply placing them in order on the battlefield.

column1: • If a face-down permanent leaves the battlefield
column2: you must reveal it. You must also reveal all face-down spells and permanents you control if you leave the game or if the game ends."

column1: 2x; Fierce Invocation; Promotional: Non-Release; Foil; 5; 4R; 2; 0; 0; C; 0; Sorcery; "Manifest the top card of your library

column3: put it onto the battlefield face down as a 2/2 creature. Turn it face up any time for its mana cost if it's a creature card.)"; "• The face-down permanent is a 2/2 creature with no name
column4: mana cost
column5: creature types
column6: or abilities. It's colorless and has a converted mana cost of 0. Other effects that apply to the permanent can still grant or change any of these characteristics.

column1: • Any time you have priority
column2: you may turn a manifested creature face up by revealing that it's a creature card (ignoring any copy effects or type-changing effects that might be applying to it) and paying its mana cost. This is a special action. It doesn't use the stack and can't be responded to.

column1: • If a manifested creature would have morph if it were face up
column2: you may also turn it face up by paying its morph cost.

column1: • Unlike a face-down creature that was cast using the morph ability
column2: a manifested creature may still be turned face up after it loses its abilities if it's a creature card.

column1: • Because the permanent is on the battlefield both before and after it's turned face up
column2: turning a permanent face up doesn't cause any enters-the-battlefield abilities to trigger.

column1: • Because face-down creatures don't have names
column2: they can't have the same name as any other creature
column3: even another face-down creature.

column1: • A permanent that turns face up or face down changes characteristics but is otherwise the same permanent. Spells and abilities that were targeting that permanent
column2: as well as Auras and Equipment that were attached to the permanent
column3: aren't affected.

column1: • Turning a permanent face up or face down doesn't change whether that permanent is tapped or untapped.
• At any time
column2: you can look at a face-down permanent you control. You can't look at face-down permanents you don't control unless an effect allows you to or instructs you to.

column1: • If a face-down permanent you control leaves the battlefield
column2: you must reveal it. You must also reveal all face-down spells and permanents you control if you leave the game or if the game ends.

column1: • You must ensure that your face-down spells and permanents can easily be differentiated from each other. You're not allowed to mix up the cards that represent them on the battlefield in order to confuse other players. The order they entered the battlefield should remain clear. Common methods for indicating this include using markers or dice
column2: or simply placing them in order on the battlefield. You must also track how each became face down (manifested
column3: cast face down using the morph ability
column4: and so on).

column1: • There are no cards in the Fate Reforged set that would turn a face-down instant or sorcery card on the battlefield face up
column2: but some older cards can try to do this. If something tries to turn a face-down instant or sorcery card on the battlefield face up
column3: reveal that card to show all players it's an instant or sorcery card. The permanent remains on the battlefield face down. Abilities that trigger when a permanent turns face up won't trigger
column4: because even though you revealed the card
column5: it never turned face up.

column1: • Some older Magic sets feature double-faced cards
column2: which have a Magic card face on each side rather than a Magic card face on one side and a Magic card back on the other. The rules for double-faced cards are changing slightly to account for the possibility that they are manifested. If a double-faced card is manifested
column3: it will be put onto the battlefield face down. While face down
column4: it can't transform. If the front face of the card is a creature card
column5: you can turn it face up by paying its mana cost. If you do
column6: its front face will be up. A double-faced permanent on the battlefield still can't be turned face down."
